title: Are there some similarities between Cuneiform and Chinese logograms? - Quora

response.answer_text: Similar like whales and icthyosaurs…it depends upon what time-axis you examine. Different writing systems, borne from very different cultures…functioning as a means of transferring knowledge across time. Cuneiform in clay tablets, was popularized at a time when Xian symbols were carved into human bone as amulets. Cuneiform of Sumer is not same as Cuneiform of Akkad or Ebla or of Persian Empire…the cuneiform writing system is a mish-mash of logograms, ideograms syllabary and phonetic symbols. Ancient logograms of Xian are symbolic one-to-one pictogram to object…neither syllabary or phonetic. Cuneiform emerges in a time of God-kings in mesopotamia…Xian logograms emerge AFTER trade commences with Ur along what would eventually be known as “Silk Road”. Another way of looking at Ancient asian writing systems is akin to looking at the cones and tokens of ancient Jericho on 10th century BCE — few knew how to write so they had artisans formulate a symbol, on an amulet, that was used as an identity…a one-to-one pictogram. Thus Cuneiform evolved from logographic, to syllabic, then phonetic. Cuneiform was the writing system of Xerxes, Cyrus and Darius in Persia roughly 6th century BCE…but Jews never brought cuneiform back to the levant when Darius liberated them from bondage in Babylon. Jews returned to Ktav assir — purely phonetic, upon returning to Judea. To this day, Chinese logograms of 2,000 years ago can be read by chinese readers…but the Xian logograms are not well documented, thus, rarely identifiable. There was an older writing system than cuneiform which operated in same time-axis.

There are basic shapes that have recurred for circa 30,000 years. Marija Gimbutas covers them in her many books. The commonest appear to be shapes that we recognize as “V,” “W,” “X,” and “Y.” Note that they are all related shapes in that they share some congruence (“V” is in all of them, for example). I can show that V = Female for 6,400 years using https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denise_Schmandt-Besserat’s token data. This is pre-cuneiform. Schmandt-Besserat shows a clear relationship between some tokens and cuneiform. Tokens were widespread, and were abundant in Mesopotamia. In Sumerian and Akkadian cuneiform, vaginas (an extension of that “V” shape) are very well represented: Vaginas Depicted in Sumerian: a Database. When something does an act as amazing as producing another, it carries a lot of meaning. That meaning is used to express other meanings, such as “spouse” and “lamb” and “pure,” as well as “defile” and “insulting” and “plow.” The worst word in Chinese is the same part of the female genitalia as the worst word in English, and it’s where the baby comes out. This sounds like jealousy to me, for experts seem to agree that men wrote language. We can only guess about the topics that human speech covered before writing existed, but once written language started, so did the domination of females. I believe this is because females can produce what males cannot. In 13 different languages, the sounds of “B” and “V” have an association (Why do the sound of "B" and "V" have an association in at least 13 different languages?). In Chinese, “cunt” is /be/: 屄 bi1. This character represents “bottom cave,” which is what a vagina is (sticklers will say that 尸 is a “corpse, body,” but there are scores of examples where the character represents a bottom). Note the upside down “V” shape: 八. This “B/V” association is orthogonally different to those “B/V” associations found in languages like Latin, Spanish, etc. where “V” is pronounced as a “B.” Linguists chalk this up to Lenition, but they fail to recognize that the original alphabet (of which all alphabets appear to have descended say the experts) went “A, B, V…” The letters “B” and “V” are very close. I think because they are representations of female genitalia. Chinese has both a “B” shape and a “V” shape. And so does Sumerian. We must use anthropology, psychology, creation myths, indeed all written and pictorial material across all cultures in order to ferret out what the ancient writers were really conveying. Part of the sleuthing is realizing that ideas are conflated, such as “mother,” “nipples,” “breasts,” and “milk.” Here is “milk” in Chinese:  The character on the left means “female.” The “B”-shaped character on the right means “to be” and it provides the sound “nai3” to this word. The doubling of the consonants: /tt/ show up in many languages as representative of “breasts,” “nipples,” or for the concept of “large”: Titanic, Grand Tetons, even the word “title” because it is something that goes before a name, and that prefix is to what we pay attention. In addition to Chinese, we see in the unrelated written language of Maya glyphs, a similar bilateral depiction for the word “mother”:  John Montgomery, Dictionary of Maya Hieroglyphs Note the breast imagery and the bilateral symmetry of two humps. There are both structural and graphic parallels. Some pictographs and simple ideograms had developed as part of accounting systems for thousands of years.The invention of “full writing” or arbitrary speech transcription was by starting to use existing symbols not just for a word, but for the sound of that word, even for where that sound occurs in other words. Thus the ideographs became a set of phonetic symbols.With multiple similar-sounding words represented by the same syllable, scribes started to annotate with category markers to disambiguate. These are usually called radicals in Chinese and https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Determinative by Sumerian scholars.From recognizable drawings, scribes abstracted the characters for quick writing, making them compositions of a small number of standard strokes depending on writing technology, the reed stylus in Mesopotamia and the writing brush in China.
